thread.section_title: The Portland Press Herald / Maine Sunday Telegram » Sports
thread.title: Dodgers beat Mets 5-2

author: The Associated Pres
title: Dodgers beat Mets 5-2
text:
Read Article 
LOS ANGELES – Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada broke his right leg when a takeout slide by Chase Utley flipped him during a four-run rally in the seventh inning, and the Los Angeles Dodgers beat New York 5-2 Saturday night to tie their NL Division Series at one game apiece. 
The Mets were leading 2-1 when the Dodgers put runners at the corners with one out against Noah Syndergaard. Bartolo Colon relieved, and Howie Kendrick hit a grounder up the middle. Dodgers’ third basemen Justin Turner celebrates scoring on a double by outfielder Andre Ethier against the Mets in the fourth inning of Game 2 of the National League Division Series on Saturday. The Associated Press Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada goes over the top of Dodgers second baseman Chase Utley in the seventh inning Saturday. Tejada broke his leg on the play. The Associated Press Related Headlines Cubs beat Cardinals to tie NLDS 1-1 Search photos available for purchase: Photo Store → 
Second baseman Daniel Murphy flipped to Tejada, who took the throw awkwardly for an apparent force as Utley slid past the bag and slammed into him, causing Tejada to flip over as the tying run scored from third. 
Tejada was put on a flatbed vehicle after an air cast was placed on his leg. The Mets said Tejada sustained a fractured right fibula. Utley was ruled safe on a video review, which determined Tejada’s foot missed the bag. Utley also appeared not to touch the base. 
Adrian Gonzalez followed with a two-run double off Addison Reed and scored on Justin Turner’s double. 
Zack Greinke (1-0), the major leagues’ ERA leader, allowed two runs and five hits in seven innings. He struck out eight and walked none a night after teammate Clayton Kershaw fanned 11 while losing his fifth straight postseason game. 
Syndergaard (0-1) gave up three runs and five hits in 6 1/3 innings. He struck out nine and walked four in following up Jacob deGrom’s 13-strikeout performance in winning Game 1. Eight of Syndergaard’s first 36 pitches reached 100 mph or more over the first two innings on an unseasonable 90-degree evening. 
The action shifts to Citi Field in New York for Game 3 Monday, when Brett Anderson tries to pitch the Dodgers back into the best-of-five series against the Mets’ Matt Harvey. Share
